title: Hakuson Kuriyagawa suffered misfortune in his personal life: he had to have one leg amputated due to infection in 1919. He died the day after the Great Kanto Earthquake struck on 1 September 1923, because he was late in escaping from the tsunami that hit his villa on the shore of Sagami Bay. Hakuson’s achievement was forgotten in Japan after his death, but his reputation grew posthumously in China through Lu Xun’s translation. Kuriyagawa’s works first acquainted Chinese people with basic Western literary concepts such as “symbolism” or “decadence” in Chinese
